Parameters.Text: Welcome to Mindtrails Movement! This initial session will be a bit longer than future sessions. You'll first be asked to complete some surveys about your mental health and thinking patterns. Then, we'll give you some more information about the rationale for this program and explain how to get the most out of the app. You'll have the opportunity to set up a meeting with the research team at the end of this session if you have any questions or concerns. Ready to get started? Hit the Next button below to begin filling out questionnaires.
What is your gender identity?
What sex were you assigned at birth?
What is your birth year?
What is your race? Please select all that apply.
What is your ethnicity?
What is your highest educational attainment?
What is your relationship status?

Buttons: 1::Single, but currently engaged to be married
2::Single, but currently living with someone in a marriage-like relationship
In a domestic or civil union

Parameters.Text: What is your employment status?
What is your household annual income, before taxes and other deductions (in US dollars or equivalent)?
How many CAG repeats do you have on your pathologic gene?

Items: Unknown or prefer not to answer

Parameters.Text: Have you or others around you noticed that you have abnormal movements sometimes?
How old were you (in years) when these abnormal movements first became noticeable?
How old were you (in years) when you were first diagnosed with Huntington's Disease?
How did you learn about MindTrails-Movement? (select all that apply)

Buttons: 2::From a newsletter or email associated with a HD resource (e.g., HDSA newsletter, HSG email, HDBuzz)
5::In-person event (e.g., HDSA Annual Convention, Team Hope Walk, Education Day)

Parameters.Text: We would like to ask a few questions about your mental health and treatment history. Answers to these personal questions are kept confidential, but they help us improve MindTrails-Movement by figuring out for whom it works well.
Are you currently struggling with any of the following mental disorders? Please select all that apply.

Buttons: ^17::I am not struggling with a mental disorder

Parameters.Text: Are you currently receiving any help for issues related to mental health? Please select all that apply, or "I am not receiving help".

Buttons:
Therapy::Therapy (talking with a trained professional)

Examples: Psychologist, licensed mental health practitioner (LMHC), school counselor, social worker, marriage and family therapist, group therapist

Prescription:: Prescription medications

Examples: Psychiatrist, medical doctor

Social::Seeking other social support (talking with non-professionals)

Examples: Teacher, family member, friend, religious leader, coach

SelfHelp::Self-guided help

Examples: Self-help book, blogs, online intervention (other than MindTrails-Movement), mobile applications

Parameters.Text:
Has therapy (talking with a trained professional) been helpful? 

1 = Not helpful at all 4 = Somewhat helpful 7=Extremely helpful

Have prescription medications been helpful? 

1 = Not helpful at all 4 = Somewhat helpful 7=Extremely helpful

Has a support group been helpful? 

1 = Not helpful at all 4 = Somewhat helpful 7=Extremely helpful

Has seeking other social support (talking with non-professionals) been helpful? 

1 = Not helpful at all 4 = Somewhat helpful 7=Extremely helpful

Has self-guided help been helpful? 

1 = Not helpful at all 4 = Somewhat helpful 7=Extremely helpful

Has over-the-counter medications and/or supplements been helpful? 

1 = Not helpful at all 4 = Somewhat helpful 7=Extremely helpful

Has what you specified in "other" been helpful? 

1 = Not helpful at all 4 = Somewhat helpful 7=Extremely helpful
There are many reasons people do not receive help. Why are you not receiving mental health treatment? Please select all that apply.

Buttons: 0::I don't think a prescription medication would help me
1::I don't like the idea of taking prescription medication
2::I can't afford to pay for treatment
3::I don't want to talk to a mental health professional (e.g., a therapist)
4::I don't think that a mental health professional can help me
5::It is hard to find a mental health professional near me
6::I don't know how to find a mental health professional
I don't want to be asked to face my fears (e.g., not wanting to interact with a spider for a person with spider fear)
8::I don't want to talk about my feelings
I had treatment previously and didn't find it helpful
10::I don't need help at this time

Parameters.Text: In the past two months, have there been any changes to your mental health treatment? Check all that apply.
Please specify any medication changes in the past 2 months:
Do you have moderate-to-severe anxiety or depression symptoms?
How long have you been experiencing moderate-to-severe anxiety or depression symptoms?
How long have you been experiencing moderate-to-severe anxiety or depression symptoms?

Instructions: Here are some descriptions of situations in which it is not quite clear what is happening. After each one, you will see 3 possible explanations for the situation. Please imagine yourself in each situation, then rate the extent to which you think each explanation would be likely to be true if you found yourself in that situation. Please provide a response for each of the 3 explanations under each question.

You hear a knock on the front door. When you open the door, no one is there. Why? 

The person who knocked forgot something in their car, and they will be right back.

You hear a knock on the front door. When you open the door, no one is there. Why? 

Someone is playing a joke on you and ran away after knocking.

You hear a knock on the front door. When you open the door, no one is there. Why? 

The knock was from a delivery person who left after dropping off a package.

Instructions: Here are some descriptions of situations in which it is not quite clear what is happening. After each one, you will see 3 possible explanations for the situation. Please imagine yourself in each situation, then rate the extent to which you think each explanation would be likely to be true if you found yourself in that situation. Please provide a response for each of the 3 explanations under each question.

At the grocery store, you see a recent acquaintance but are unable to remember her name. Why? 

You could not hear her name clearly the first time she said it.

At the grocery store, you see a recent acquaintance but are unable to remember her name. Why? 

You are getting dementia from your disease.

At the grocery store, you see a recent acquaintance but are unable to remember her name. Why? 

It is normal to forget the name of someone you have only met once.

While eating with your family at a local restaurant, your server rarely stops by your table to check on you. Why? 

They are scared by your movements and avoiding you.

While eating with your family at a local restaurant, your server rarely stops by your table to check on you. Why? 

The restaurant is under-staffed and the server is busy.

While eating with your family at a local restaurant, your server rarely stops by your table to check on you. Why? 

The server is new and probably needs additional training.

You are playing a game for the first time with friends and new acquaintances. On your turn, you ask for a reminder of the rules, and the others become quiet. What are they thinking? 

They are thinking that they also had a tough time learning this game at first.

You are playing a game for the first time with friends and new acquaintances. On your turn, you ask for a reminder of the rules, and the others become quiet. What are they thinking? 

They are thinking of how best to explain the rules.

You are playing a game for the first time with friends and new acquaintances. On your turn, you ask for a reminder of the rules, and the others become quiet. What are they thinking? 

They are thinking your disease makes you slow and wishing you had not been invited to play.

While cleaning up with a family member after dinner, you drop a glass and it shatters. Why? 

Your family member made a joke that distracted you while you were reaching for the glass.

While cleaning up with a family member after dinner, you drop a glass and it shatters. Why? 

The glass was slippery after being washed.

While cleaning up with a family member after dinner, you drop a glass and it shatters. Why? 

Your disease is progressing faster than normal, and you should no longer help with chores.

You are talking to a neighbor and have difficulty saying a word. What is your neighbor thinking? 

They are thinking that something must be wrong with you.

You are talking to a neighbor and have difficulty saying a word. What is your neighbor thinking? 

They are thinking about the next thing they want to tell you.

You are talking to a neighbor and have difficulty saying a word. What is your neighbor thinking? 

They are trying to figure out which word you are trying to say so that they can help you.

You receive an email from your bank that you forgot to pay a bill. What does this mean? 

You should set up bill pay reminders - lots of people need reminders like this.

You receive an email from your bank that you forgot to pay a bill. What does this mean? 

You are no long fit to manage your own finances.

You receive an email from your bank that you forgot to pay a bill. What does this mean? 

You will have to pay a fee for late payment.

Your doctor recommends a new type of exercise class to help your symptoms. You are hesitant. Why? 

You will probably be bad at it and embarass yourself.

Your doctor recommends a new type of exercise class to help your symptoms. You are hesitant. Why? 

You are worried that it will be too expensive.

Your doctor recommends a new type of exercise class to help your symptoms. You are hesitant. Why? 

The class is far away, and you are not sure you can make it on a regular basis.

You receive an unexpected message from your doctor that they want to talk to you about starting a new medication. Why? 

A new medication that might help you was just approved by the FDA.

You receive an unexpected message from your doctor that they want to talk to you about starting a new medication. Why? 

Your symptoms are uncontrollable, and they do not know what else to try.

You receive an unexpected message from your doctor that they want to talk to you about starting a new medication. Why? 

The new medication may have fewer side effects than your current medication.

You ask your family member to go for a walk with you, but they do not want to go. Why? 

They are tired.

You ask your family member to go for a walk with you, but they do not want to go. Why? 

They have a prior commitment.

You ask your family member to go for a walk with you, but they do not want to go. Why? 

They are embarrased to be seen with you because of the way you walk.

Your younger family member is applying for a job. You offer to help with the application, and they decline. Why? 

They think your disease makes your opinion less relevant.

Your younger family member is applying for a job. You offer to help with the application, and they decline. Why? 

They do not really want this job.

Your younger family member is applying for a job. You offer to help with the application, and they decline. Why? 

Several other people have already helped them, and they are ready to submit the application.

A person in the grocery store stares at you blankly as you stumble and knock over a display. What are they thinking? 

They are thinking that you must have mis-stepped which can happen to anyone.

A person in the grocery store stares at you blankly as you stumble and knock over a display. What are they thinking? 

They are thinking about their grocery list and did not notice.

A person in the grocery store stares at you blankly as you stumble and knock over a display. What are they thinking? 

They are thinking that something is wrong with you.

While eating breakfast, you cough while trying to swallow. Why? 

You took a bite that was too large.

While eating breakfast, you cough while trying to swallow. Why? 

You have lost your ability to swallow and will soon have to get a feeding tube.

While eating breakfast, you cough while trying to swallow. Why? 

Because of your disease, it has become more difficult for your body to cooridnate swallowing.

Instructions: In this section, 14 situations are presented in which it is not quite clear what is happening. Please rate the extent to which you think each of the three explanations for a situation would be likely to be true if you found yourself in that situation. Do not worry if your ratings appear to be different from your previous answers, and please do not change any of your original answers.

You have visitors over for dinner, and they leave sooner than expected. Why? 

They did not wish to outstay their welcome.

You have visitors over for dinner, and they leave sooner than expected. Why? 

They have another pressing engagement to go to.

You have visitors over for dinner, and they leave sooner than expected. Why? 

They did not enjoy the visit and were bored with your company.

You feel short of breath. Why? 

You are developing the flu.

You feel short of breath. Why? 

You are about to suffocate or stop breathing.

You feel short of breath. Why? 

You are physically "out of shape."

Your vision has become slightly blurred. Why? 

You have strained your eyes slightly.

Your vision has become slightly blurred. Why? 

You need to get glasses or change your existing glasses.

Your vision has become slightly blurred. Why? 

This is the sign of a serious illness.

You go into a shop, and the assistant ignores you. Why? 

They are bored with their job and this makes them rude.

You go into a shop, and the assistant ignores you. Why? 

They are concentrating very hard on something else.

You go into a shop, and the assistant ignores you. Why? 

They find you irritating and resent your presence.

You feel light-headed and weak. Why? 

You are about to faint.

You feel light-headed and weak. Why? 

You need to get something to eat.

You feel light-headed and weak. Why? 

You didn't get enough sleep last night.

You smell smoke. What's burning? 

Your house is on fire.

You feel light-headed and weak. Why? 

Some food is burning.

You feel light-headed and weak. Why? 

Someone is smoking a cigarette.

A friend suggests that you change the way you're doing a job in your house. Why? 

They are trying to be helpful.

A friend suggests that you change the way you're doing a job in your house. Why? 

They think you're incompetent.

A friend suggests that you change the way you're doing a job in your house. Why? 

They have done the job more often and know an easier way.

Your chest feels uncomfortable and tight. Why? 

You have indigestion.

Your chest feels uncomfortable and tight. Why? 

You have a sore muscle.

Your chest feels uncomfortable and tight. Why? 

Something is wrong with your heart.

You wake up with a jolt in the middle of the night, thinking you heard a noise, but all is quiet. Why woke you up? 

You were woken by a dream.

You wake up with a jolt in the middle of the night, thinking you heard a noise, but all is quiet. Why woke you up? 

A burgler broke into your house.

You wake up with a jolt in the middle of the night, thinking you heard a noise, but all is quiet. Why woke you up? 

A door or window rattled in the wind.

You are introduced to someone at a party. The person fails to reply to a question you ask. Why? 

They did not hear the question.

You are introduced to someone at a party. The person fails to reply to a question you ask. Why? 

They think you are uninteresting and boring.

You are introduced to someone at a party. The person fails to reply to a question you ask. Why? 

They were preoccupied with something else at the time.

You notice that your heart is beating quickly and pounding. Why? 

Because you have been physically active.

You notice that your heart is beating quickly and pounding. Why? 

Because there is something wrong with your heart.
You notice that your heart is beating quickly and pounding. Why? vBecause you are feeling really excited.

Suddenly, you feel confused and find it hard to think straight. Why? 

You are going out of your mind.

Suddenly, you feel confused and find it hard to think straight. Why? 

You are coming down with a cold.

Suddenly, you feel confused and find it hard to think straight. Why? 

You've been working too hard and need a rest.

A letter marked "URGENT" arrives. What is in the letter? 

It is junk mail designed to attract your attention.

A letter marked "URGENT" arrives. What is in the letter? 

You forgot to pay a bill.

A letter marked "URGENT" arrives. What is in the letter? 

It is news that someone you know has died or is seriously ill.

You notice your heart is pounding, and you feel breathless, dizzy, and unreal. Why? 

You have been overdoing it and are overtired.

You notice your heart is pounding, and you feel breathless, dizzy, and unreal. Why? 

Something you ate disagreed with you.

You notice your heart is pounding, and you feel breathless, dizzy, and unreal. Why? 

You are dangerously ill or going mad.

Please complete each item below. Think about your current level of functioning compared to before your HD diagnosis.
How would you rate your ability to work or perform the occupation you had before your HD diagnosis?

Buttons: 1::No longer able to perform usual job, but able to volunteer or assist in less demanding work
2::Reduced performance, but still able to work in usual job

Parameters.Text: How would you rate your ability to manage finances?
How would you rate your ability to perform chores around the house?
How would you rate your ability to perform basic daily activities such as bathing, grooming, and dressing?

Buttons: 1::Unable to perform fine motor tasks (e.g., buttons, cutting food)

Parameters.Text: Which of the following best describes your current living situation:

Buttons: 0::Living full-time in a nursing home or skilled nursing facility
1::Living at home with support from professional caregiver(s)

Parameters.Text: MindTrails-Movement is designed to help you change the way you think about common but potentially stressful situations in order to reduce anxiety and stress. When you complete sessions in the app, you will be asked to read brief stories about situations that often produce anxiety and fill in missing letters to complete words, fill in entire words, or come up with new stories that are personally relevant to you. To help familiarize you with the program and help you get the most out of this experience, we would like you complete a few short exercises and watch some brief videos explaining how Hoos Think Calmly works. You will also be presented with three example stories so that you can begin to get the hang of the training. Click next to get started!

The purpose of this quick exercise is to demonstrate what imagination-based thinking is. You will imagine what seeing, touching, and smelling a lemon is like. Please imagine this as if you are really experiencing it.

In this exercise, and throughout the training program, please remember to imagine what is happening through your own eyes, similar to the picture on the left. This is more effective than viewing the situation as an outside observer, like the picture on the right.
Okay...let's begin! Imagine you are holding the lemon in your right hand, and you can feel its shape and its weight.
Now imagine you are shining a light on the lemon, and you can see the waxy and lumpy texture of the yellow skin.
Now imagine that you scratch the skin with your fingernail, then you bring the lemon up to your nose, and you can smell the fresh zesty juice from the skin.
Now imagine that you cut the lemon in half, and you bring one half of it up for a closer look. You can see the juicy flesh in the shape of segments that look like a wagon wheel.
Now imagine that you squeeze the lemon and some of the juice squirts right into your eyes, and it is really stinging, making your eyes water.
That was the Lemon Exercise! Don't worry if you didn't experience all of the sensations strongly. This is completely normal.

In this exercise, please think of an UPCOMING situation that you expect will make you feel anxious, worried, or scared. Pick a situation that you worry might go badly, or that you expect will evoke symptoms related to anxiety (e.g., racing heart, sweating). Any situation that will make you feel quite anxious or scared will work, as long as it is a situation that is likely to actually happen.
Please describe the situation in a few words:

Please imagine the situation as vividly as possible (i.e., so that it feels very real). Try to imagine you are actually in the situation. Play out the specific parts of the situation in your head. Try to imagine using all your senses while you think about this situation. Think about the things you would see, hear, and smell if you were really in that situation. Think about the kinds of things you would think or feel if you were actually there.

Play this situation in your head for the next 20 seconds. 

The screen will change in 20 seconds.

How anxious did you feel (at the highest level of anxiety) as you completed the imagery task? Press on the bar to see the slider. 

0 = Absolutely no anxiety. 

10 = Totally anxious.
How vividly did you imagine the situation?
How likely is it that the situation or task will turn out well versus turn out badly?

Buttons: Very likely to turn out well
Somewhat likely to turn out well
Somewhat likely to turn out badly
Very likely to turn out badly

Parameters.Text: If this situation did turn out badly, how well or badly would you be able to handle it?
Please press play on the training video below to learn more!
Contributing to a discussion

Your boss calls a meeting to discuss a new project that will involve most of the staff at your office. You are suddenly asked to contribute your ideas to the discussion. You quickly come up with some ideas on the spot and think that your colleagues will find your ideas to be...

Parameters.Text: We want Mindtrails Movement to meet your needs. When you complete training sessions in the app or browse resources in the on-demand resource library, you'll notice a button that looks like a star on the top right-hand corner of your screen. By clicking on the star, you can add the info you find most helpful (e.g., short stories, tips for managing stress) to your own personal Favorites page. You can then revisit your favorite parts of the app whenever you'd like by choosing the Favorites tile from the Mindtrails Movement homepage!
Please press play on the training video below to learn more!
Attention in store

You are in a store and accidentally knock over a few picture frames in one of the aisles. You feel your cheeks become hot as people in the store turn and look at you. When the shop owner comes over to rearrange the picture frames, they are...

Inputs.Name: Attention in store_Social Situations_puzzle
Inputs.IncorrectFeedback: Whoops! That doesn't look right. Please wait a moment and try again.

Inputs.IncorrectFeedback: Whoops! That doesn't look right. Please wait a moment and try again.

Parameters.Text: The other shoppers probably think you are ...

Your friend buys you a cake for your birthday. When they bring it over in the evening, they note that they have recently gotten over being ill. Holding the cake, you think your chances of becoming sick are pretty...

Parameters.Text: What are you hoping to get out of the MindTrails-Movement program? Select all that apply.

Buttons: I want to think more flexibly and less negatively.
I want to be able to manage stressful situations more effectively.
I want to reduce my stress and/or anxiety.
I want to practice skills I've learned or am currently learning from a mental healthcare provider.
I want to maintain the gains I've made during mental health treatment.
I want to avoid a return of anxiety and/or stress I've experienced in the past.

Parameters.Text: Great job! We hope that this brief training helped clarify the purpose of these short stories and what you might be able to get out of MindTrails-Movement. Moving forward, you'll be able to choose areas of life that are causing the most stress so that the stories you read will be more relevant to you. During future sessions, you will also receive tips that are designed to help you manage your emotions, connect with resources at UVA, and apply what you learn from the short stories to your own life.

For the next 6 weeks, you will receive notifications prompting you to open the app to complete activities and surveys. We hope that you will use the app 1-2 times daily, but we understand that life can get in the way and that you may need to skip some sessions. That's okay, but just remember that the program only lasts for 6 weeks. You will also be able to access the contents of the app (activities, resources, etc.) at any time by visiting the on-demand library from the homepage.
Still have questions? Contact the team at js6zn@uvahealth.org! We would be happy to schedule a Zoom call to address any questions or concerns you may have.
